entry.title: Combined summary - Graftroot: Private and efficient surrogate scripts under the taproot assumption
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev mailing list has been discussing various methods related to the rotation of keys and delegates. One method discussed allows for unilateral key rotation without invalidating the interests of other parties in the existing multisig, and does not require any on-chain transaction, only storing the signed delegation. The discussion also raises the idea of introducing functionality that makes a script invalid after a certain time, which can exclude old delegates by timing/block height arguments or even pre-sign delegates for different periods of time. Another topic discussed is the case where a delegate is signed conditional on another delegate being signed, and how something like segwit is required so that one side's delegation can be referred to by a signature-stable identity.In regards to the Taproot protocol for Bitcoin, it suffers from a limitation that only provides for one alternative natively. However, with the Graftroot protocol, an unlimited number of alternatives can be provided while maintaining efficiency and privacy. The participants establish a threshold key, optionally with a taproot alternative, just as they do with Taproot. At any time, they can delegate their ability to sign to a surrogate script by signing that script (and just the script) with their taproot key and sharing that delegation with whomever they choose. A naive implementation of this idea requires a complete signature every time a surrogate is used, which means 64 bytes of data. However, the non-interactive schnorr aggregation trick can be applied to merge the S values of all graftroots and signatures in a transaction into a single aggregate.The context also mentions a suggestion made by Jeremy on February 9, 2018, about improving the utility of a construction by introducing functionality that makes a script invalid after a certain time, and the thread was tagged with "nExpiryTime" for future reference. In addition, there is a discussion about binding grafts to a particular transaction and whether signing H(txid, script) instead of H(script) could potentially work. However, knowing the txid in advance is required for this method to work.Overall, the context provides insights into various discussions related to Bitcoin-dev mailing list that are focused on improving existing methods and introducing new ones to enhance privacy, efficiency, and scalability. The non-interactive schnorr aggregation trick and Graftroot protocol are promising developments in this regard. However, it is important to keep in mind potential risks associated with reusing keys or delegates in foolish ways.
